Key Arguments: The legislation may shift speech from libertarian to totalitarian rhetoric.
Concerns about who decides what constitutes misinformation or disinformation.
Fear of government control over public opinion and journalism.
The process of fact-checking and verifying information is costly and time-consuming.
The ACMA is not equipped to handle the responsibility of determining misinformation.
Main Themes: Challenges in defining and regulating misinformation
Resource and capability limitations of ACMA
Notable Quotes: Ultimately, I believe that the best society is one that is open to dialogue, being able to poke at the arguments of others, and resolve the issue at hand with the best solution.
Who should be the arbiter of disinformation, misinformation, hate speech, etc.?
This will cost a lot of money and time, for which in a quickly changing and developing world online, can be expensive and take long hours of analysis.
